Etymology. The specific name is the union of the words dimidius , a masculine adjective that means ‘half’, and aster , a masculine noun meaning ‘star’. The name is a reference to the shape of the female opisthosoma, which resembles the upper half of a five-pointed star. Noun in apposition.

Diagnosis. Females of
E. dimidiaster
sp. nov.
resemble those of
E. taczanowskii
in the shape and proportion of the opisthosomal projections, but can be distinguished by the glabrous prosoma, absence of the upside down Vshaped mark on clypeus and thoracic portion with no LBL ( Figs 3A, B ). The epigynal plate differs from those of other species of the genus by the lateral folds that do not join posteriorly to form a median septum. Instead, the septum is formed by an anterior elevation of the median field ( Fig. 3C ). Males are almost indistinguishable from those of
E. trituberculatus
, being only recognizable by the pointed and stouter opisthosomal projections and by the position of TF at four o’clock ( Fig. 4C ).
